item.title: GENRE: ___Lo-Fi___
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
Lex:

Maybe there are others that are free?

We did get a little off-topic‚Ä¶
As far as free options, I think Garageband is a great choice.

You could try any of:

  • The inbuilt bitcrusher.
  • The inbuilt distortion.
  • Timestretch a loop to double/half it‚Äôs tempo, bounce and timestretch back to the original tempo.
  • Roll off a little of the top end with a low-pass filter.
  • Over compress a sound with very fast attack and release times.
  • Push the faders into the red and bounce down.

Read full topic

Maybe there are others that are free? If not then no biggie, I‚Äôm sure I can make something sound like a cassette tape in Auxy.

Read full topic

item.title: GENRE: ___Lo-Fi___
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Polar:

I have an amazing app that I use to convert files, it‚Äôs called File Converter. I believe it is only $2 or $3, and it converts files very fast.

Not sure what you‚Äôre suggesting here.
I think you‚Äôve misunderstood what I was talking about.

I already have plenty of tools for converting audio between formats.

Or are you saying that the app can convert AUv3 plugins to standalone iOS apps?
(I suspect not.)

Read full topic

item.title: GENRE: ___Lo-Fi___
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
akabillposters:

The iOS version is described as ‚ÄòAUv3 / Standalone‚Äô, but it‚Äôs not properly standalone in the way that (e.g.) Grand Finale is. i.e. You can‚Äôt import and export WAV files.

Always frustrating when apps aren‚Äôt labelled properly, but (not owning Haaze) it seems like the kind of app that would work best on a channel strip during mixdown, as opposed to in isolation?

Did you try it with something like Aum?

Read full topic

item.title: GENRE: ___Lo-Fi___
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
It might be worth looking into one of the options that natively exports from app to Ableton Live set ‚Äì there‚Äôs a few that do it (definitely the KORG stuff, I think ampify/Novation too). For someone who is a Live user I can see how that‚Äôs SUPER BENEFICIAL workflow wise ‚Äì start out on iOS as scratch pad / sketch and then finalize / flesh everything out in Live.

Propellerhead fan boys (myself included) are left in the dust. We get Figure and Take‚Ä¶ and unfortunately, Figure just dumps a wave loop to Reason if you pick something up from Allihoopa (whoopdy do!) - it doesn‚Äôt even dump separate stems it just plops in a combined wave file lol.

Read full topic

item.title: GENRE: ___Lo-Fi___
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
For sure.
There‚Äôs a chance that I may end up buying the it again, down the line, though only while my process stays iOS-centric.

Although, I think I‚Äôm more likely to shift to mobile + desktop than to consolidate on an iOS process.
(Ableton 10 [which I haven‚Äôt yet upgraded to] has some new stereo tools, so maybe Haaze won‚Äôt be something I want by that point.)

Read full topic

item.title: GENRE: ___Lo-Fi___
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
Yeah, that stinks it wasn‚Äôt labeled properly

I do think most devs are going to be shifting efforts toward AUv3 / integration of some kind since that‚Äôs where the landscape is headed. Having been doing this since before the Audiobus days, it‚Äôs astounding how far iOS music production has come. Most people will blow right past an app if it isn‚Äôt AUv3 compatible, unless it‚Äôs meant to truly be an island

Read full topic

item.title: GENRE: ___Lo-Fi___
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Wish they had more standalone iOS apps though.

Accidentally bought Haaze recently (Stereo tool).

The iOS version is described as ‚ÄòAUv3 / Standalone‚Äô, but it‚Äôs not properly standalone in the way that (e.g.) Grand Finale is. i.e. You can‚Äôt import and export WAV files.

Just put in for a cancellation/refund.

Read full topic
